[0m{
  "lc": 1,
  "type": "constructor",
  "id": [
    "langchain",
    "prompts",
    "base",
    "StringPromptValue"
  ],
  "kwargs": {
    "text": "You are Destination researcher.\nA resourceful travel agent with extensive information\n        about the city, it's attractions and customs.\n\nYour personal goal is: Provide the latest and BEST insights about the destination city.TOOLS:\n------\nYou have access to the following tools:\n\nDuckDuckGo Results JSON: A wrapper around Duck Duck Go Search. Useful for when you need to answer questions about current events. Input should be a search query. Output is a JSON array of the query results\nwebsite_scrapper: Scrape websites to get additional information. Remember to pass only all links formatted in a valid comma-separated string. \n\n        ActionInput: should have all links mentioned in the provided  context and formatted to valid comma-separated string.\n\nTo use a tool, please use the exact following format:\n\n```\nThought: Do I need to use a tool? Yes\nAction: the action to take, should be one of [DuckDuckGo Results JSON, website_scrapper], just the name.\nAction Input: the input to the action\nObservation: the result of the action\n```\n\nWhen you have a response for your task, or if you do not need to use a tool, you MUST use the format:\n\n```\nThought: Do I need to use a tool? No\nFinal Answer: [your response here]This is the summary of your work so far:\nBegin! This is VERY important to you, your job depends on it!\n\nCurrent Task: \nYou must compile THE latest\nin-depth guide for someone traveling and wanting \nto have THE BEST trip ever!\nYou have tools access to gather information about key attractions, local customs,\nspecial events, and daily activity recommendations.\nSearch for the best spots to go to, the kind of place only a\nlocal would   "text": "Nomadic Matt's Travel Site\n\nTravel Better, Cheaper, Longer\n\nSearch for:\n\n  * About\n  * Blog\n    * Latest Posts\n    * The 6 Best Hostels in Cusco\n    * The Chase Sapphire Preferred Review\n    * InsureMyTrip Travel Insurance Review\n    * Popular Posts\n    * Everyone Says I’m Running Away\n    * The Ultimate Guide to Traveling Cheap\n    * Travel is a Privilege\n    * Why There’s no Perfect Time to Travel\n  * Travel Tips\n    * Get Inspired\n    * How to Save For a Trip\n    * How to Plan Your Trip\n    * Get the Right Gear\n    * Find Cheap Airfare\n    * Get Accommodation\n    * Life on the Road\n    * Solo Female Travel\n    * Family and Senior Travel\n  * Destinations\n  * Resources\n    * Blog School\n    * Favorite Travel Companies\n    * Book Accommodation\n    * Book Your Flight\n    * Get Travel Insurance\n    * Favorite Hostels\n    * Travel Credit Cards\n  * Books\n  * __\n\n  * About\n  * Blog\n    * Latest Posts\n    * The 6 Best Hostels in Cusco\n    * The Chase Sapphire Preferred Review\n    * InsureMyTrip Travel Insurance Review\n    * Popular Posts\n    * Everyone Says I’m Running Away\n    * The Ultimate Guide to Traveling Cheap\n    * Travel is a Privilege\n    * Why There’s no Perfect Time to Travel\n  * Travel Tips\n    * Get Inspired\n    * How to Save For a Trip\n    * How to Plan Your Trip\n    * Get the Right Gear\n    * Find Cheap Airfare\n    * Get Accommodation\n    * Life on the Road\n    * Solo Female Travel\n    * Family and Senior Travel\n  * Destinations\n  * Resources\n    * Blog School\n    * Favorite Travel Companies\n    * Book Accommodation\n    * Book Your Flight\n    * Get Travel Insurance\n    * Favorite Hostels\n    * Travel Credit Cards\n  * Books\n  * __\n\nHome » Travel Guides » Spain Travel Guide » Madrid Travel Guide\n\n# Madrid Travel Guide\n\nLast Updated: September 1, 2023\n\n  \nMadrid is the capital of Spain and the country’s largest city. With energetic\nvibes, world-class food, incredible architecture, museums, and a nightlife\nthat stretches until dawn, the city is one of the best in all of Europe and a\nplace most visitors love..\n\nLike its rival Barcelona, Madrid embraces the night. Dinner doesn’t happen\nuntil 9pm or 10pm and the partying doesn’t kick off until several hours after\nthat. It’s a city for night owls.\n\nThough it’s somewhat sprawling, Madrid’s numerous neighborhoods are perfect\nfor getting lost in, binging on tapas, and drinking sangria. The warmth of the\nlocals and the slowness of the meals will keep you out late as you soak in the\ncity’s pace. If you embrace the late (and long) meals and the late-night\npartying and live your life on Madrid’s terms you’ll have a much deeper,\nenriching visit.\n\nThis Madrid travel guide will give you everything you need to know to eat\nwell, save money, and see the best sights the city has to offer!\n\n#### Table of Contents\n\n  1. Things to See and Do\n  2. Typical Costs\n  3. Suggested Budget\n  4. Money-Saving Tips\n  5. Where to Stay\n  6. How to Get Around\n  7. When to Go\n  8. How to Stay Safe\n  9. Best Places to Book Your Trip\n  10. Related Blogs on Madrid\n\n### Top 5 Things to See and Do in Madrid\n\n##### 1\\. Stroll Plaza Mayor\n\nThe Plaza Mayor, which dates to the 15th century, is Madrid’s main square.\nWhile walking this plaza, which was designated a Spanish Property of Cultural\nInterest in 1985, don’t miss Ayuntamiento (the impressive city council\nbuilding), the Baroque Church of San Pedro, the 18th-century San Francisco el\nGrande Basilica, and Calle de Cuchilleros (a popular place to eat, but expect\ntourist prices).\n\n##### 2\\. Visit the Prado Museum\n\nThe Prado Museum (Museo Nacional del Prado) is one of the world’s greatest art\ngalleries and the main art museum in Spain. As one of the most-visited museums\nin the world, its dazzling display of around 20,000 works by the great\nEuropean masters is housed in an 18th-century building that opened as a museum\nin 1819. The museum is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a Spanish\nProperty of Cultural Interest, home to works by Rembrandt, Caravaggio,\nBernini, Monet, and many, many others. Admission is 15 EUR.\n\n##### 3\\. Unwind in El Retiro Park\n\nOfficially known as The Buen Retiro Park, this is the main park of Madrid. A\nUNESCO World Heritage Site, it’s the perfect place to relax on a sunny day.\nThe park dates back to the 17th century and spans over 350 acres, making it\nthe largest and most popular green space in the city. There is a large lake\nwhere you can hire a rowboat, a monument to the victims of the Madrid\nterrorist bombings (which killed 193 people and injured over 2,000 in 2004),\nand the Crystal Palace (a 19th-century conservatory that once held a human\nzoo).\n\n##### 4\\. Visit the Palacio Real\n\nThis is the official residence of the King of Spain, though it is now only\nused for state ceremonies. The palace is partially open to the public and is\nfree for EU citizens on Wednesdays. Built in the 18th century, the palace is\nthe largest functioning palace in Europe, home to over 3,400 rooms. A Spanish\nProperty of Cultural Interest, the palace was built on a former 9th-century\nMuslim fort and contains numerous works of art in its ornate interior,\nincluding pieces by Caravaggio, Juan de Flandes, and Francisco Goya. Admission\nis 12 EUR for self-guided tours and 16 EUR for a guided tour. Audio guides are\navailable for 5 EUR.\n\n##### 5\\. Take a food tour\n\nTo learn more about the history and culture behind Madrid’s cuisine, take a\nfood tour. It’s the best way to eat your way around the city sampling the best\neats Madrid has to offer while learning what makes the cuisine unique. Devour\nTours runs in-depth food tours led by expert local guides that will introduce\nyou to the food culture and its history. If you’re a foodie like me who wants\nto learn more about the history and culture behind each dish, this tour is for\nyou! Tours start at 99 EUR.\n\n### Other Things to See and Do in Madrid\n\n##### 1\\. Take a free walking tour\n\nFree walking tours are one of my favorite activities to do in a new city.\nYou’ll get the lay of the land, learn about the history and culture, and\nconnect with a local guide who can answer all your questions. New Europe, Free\nWalking Tours Madrid, and Cat’s Hostel Walking Tours are the best free tours\nin the city. Just remember to tip your guide at the end!\n\n##### 2\\. Check out Puerta del Sol\n\nThis is Madrid’s most famous and central square. Originally, it was the site\nof one of the east-facing city gates and was adorned with an image of the sun,\nhence the square’s name (“The Sun Gate”). The square is actually semi-circular\nin shape and owes its current form to the major renovation work carried out\nbetween 1854-60. There’s a stone slab on the ground in front of Casa de\nCorreos’ main entrance (the current headquarters of the Madrid regional\ngovernment) to mark kilometer 0 as this is also the center of Spain’s radial\nroad network. People congregate here on New Year’s Eve to celebrate under the\nclock on top of the Casa de Correos building. It’s tradition to eat a “lucky”\ngrape for each of the 12 strokes of midnight.\n\n##### 3\\. See flamenco dancers\n\nMadrid has been enjoying flamenco, Spain’s most famous style of dancing, since\nthe early 19th century. Based on the various folkloric music traditions of\nsouthern Spain, flamenco shows take place in many bars and taverns across the\ncity, such as Las Carboneras where you can enjoy a flamenco show with a glass\nof wine and some tapas for 42 EUR. The historic Corral de la Morería offers\nshows for 49.95 EUR, including a drink.\n\n##### 4\\. Visit the National Archaeological Museum"
}

Companies\n    * Book Accommodation\n    * Book Your Flight\n    * Get Travel Insurance\n    * Favorite Hostels\n    * Travel Credit Cards\n  * Books\n  * __\n\nHome » Travel Guides » Spain Travel Guide » Madrid Travel Guide\n\n# Madrid Travel Guide\n\nLast Updated: September 1, 2023\n\n  \nMadrid is the capital of Spain and the country’s largest city. With energetic\nvibes, world-class food, incredible architecture, museums, and a nightlife\nthat stretches until dawn, the city is one of the best in all of Europe and a\nplace most visitors love..\n\nLike its rival Barcelona, Madrid embraces the night. Dinner doesn’t happen\nuntil 9pm or 10pm and the partying doesn’t kick off until several hours after\nthat. It’s a city for night owls.\n\nThough it’s somewhat sprawling, Madrid’s numerous neighborhoods are perfect\nfor getting lost in, binging on tapas, and drinking sangria. The warmth of the\nlocals and the slowness of the meals will keep you out late as you soak in the\ncity’s pace. If you embrace the late (and long) meals and the late-night\npartying and live your life on Madrid’s terms you’ll have a much deeper,\nenriching visit.\n\nThis Madrid travel guide will give you everything you need to know to eat\nwell, save money, and see the best sights the city has to offer!\n\n#### Table of Contents\n\n  1. Things to See and Do\n  2. Typical Costs\n  3. Suggested Budget\n  4. Money-Saving Tips\n  5. Where to Stay\n  6. How to Get Around\n  7. When to Go\n  8. How to Stay Safe\n  9. Best Places to Book Your Trip\n  10. Related Blogs on Madrid\n\n### Top 5 Things to See and Do in Madrid\n\n##### 1\\. Stroll Plaza Mayor\n\nThe Plaza Mayor, which dates to the 15th century, is Madrid’s main square.\nWhile walking this plaza, which was designated a Spanish Property of Cultural\nInterest in 1985, don’t miss Ayuntamiento (the impressive city council\nbuilding), the Baroque Church of San Pedro, the 18th-century San Francisco el\nGrande Basilica, and Calle de Cuchilleros (a popular place to eat, but expect\ntourist prices).\n\n##### 2\\. Visit the Prado Museum\n\nThe Prado Museum (Museo Nacional del Prado) is one of the world’s greatest art\ngalleries and the main art museum in Spain. As one of the most-visited museums\nin the world, its dazzling display of around 20,000 works by the great\nEuropean masters is housed in an 18th-century building that opened as a museum\nin 1819. The museum is also a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a Spanish\nProperty of Cultural Interest, home to works by Rembrandt, Caravaggio,\nBernini, Monet, and many, many others. Admission is 15 EUR.\n\n##### 3\\. Unwind in El Retiro Park\n\nOfficially known as The Buen Retiro Park, this is the main park of Madrid. A\nUNESCO World Heritage Site, it’s the perfect place to relax on a sunny day.\nThe park dates back to the 17th century and spans over 350 acres, making it\nthe largest and most popular green space in the city. There is a large lake\nwhere you can hire a rowboat, a monument to the victims of the Madrid\nterrorist bombings (which killed 193 people and injured over 2,000 in 2004),\nand the Crystal Palace (a 19th-century conservatory that once held a human\nzoo).\n\n##### 4\\. Visit the Palacio Real\n\nThis is the official residence of the King of Spain, though it is now only\nused for state ceremonies. The palace is partially open to the public and is\nfree for EU citizens on Wednesdays. Built in the 18th century, the palace is\nthe largest functioning palace in Europe, home to over 3,400 rooms. A Spanish\nProperty of Cultural Interest, the palace was built on a former 9th-century\nMuslim fort and contains numerous works of art in its ornate interior,\nincluding pieces by Caravaggio, Juan de Flandes, and Francisco Goya. Admission\nis 12 EUR for self-guided tours and 16 EUR for a guided tour. Audio guides are\navailable for 5 EUR.\n\n##### 5\\. Take a food tour\n\nTo learn more about the history and culture behind Madrid’s cuisine, take a\nfood tour. It’s the best way to eat your way around the city sampling the best\neats Madrid has to offer while learning what makes the cuisine unique. Devour\nTours runs in-depth food tours led by expert local guides that will introduce\nyou to the food culture and its history. If you’re a foodie like me who wants\nto learn more about the history and culture behind each dish, this tour is for\nyou! Tours start at 99 EUR.\n\n### Other Things to See and Do in Madrid\n\n##### 1\\. Take a free walking tour\n\nFree walking tours are one of my favorite activities to do in a new city.\nYou’ll get the lay of the land, learn about the history and culture, and\nconnect with a local guide who can answer all your questions. New Europe, Free\nWalking Tours Madrid, and Cat’s Hostel Walking Tours are the best free tours\nin the city. Just remember to tip your guide at the end!\n\n##### 2\\. Check out Puerta del Sol\n\nThis is Madrid’s most famous and central square. Originally, it was the site\nof one of the east-facing city gates and was adorned with an image of the sun,\nhence the square’s name (“The Sun Gate”). The square is actually semi-circular\nin shape and owes its current form to the major renovation work carried out\nbetween 1854-60. There’s a stone slab on the ground in front of Casa de\nCorreos’ main entrance (the current headquarters of the Madrid regional\ngovernment) to mark kilometer 0 as this is also the center of Spain’s radial\nroad network. People congregate here on New Year’s Eve to celebrate under the\nclock on top of the Casa de Correos building. It’s tradition to eat a “lucky”\ngrape for each of the 12 strokes of midnight.\n\n##### 3\\. See flamenco dancers\n\nMadrid has been enjoying flamenco, Spain’s most famous style of dancing, since\nthe early 19th century. Based on the various folkloric music traditions of\nsouthern Spain, flamenco shows take place in many bars and taverns across the\ncity, such as Las Carboneras where you can enjoy a flamenco show with a glass\nof wine and some tapas for 42 EUR. The historic Corral de la Morería offers\nshows for 49.95 EUR, including a drink.\n\n##### 4\\. Visit the National Archaeological Museum\n        DETAILED SUMMARY:"
  ]

[0m{
  "text": "##### 3\\. See flamenco dancers\n\nMadrid has been enjoying flamenco, Spain’s most famous style of dancing, since\nthe early 19th century. Based on the various folkloric music traditions of\nsouthern Spain, flamenco shows take place in many bars and taverns across the\ncity, such as Las Carboneras where you can enjoy a flamenco show with a glass\nof wine and some tapas for 42 EUR. The historic Corral de la Morería offers\nshows for 49.95 EUR, including a drink.\n\n##### 4\\. Visit the National Archaeological Museum\n\nThis museum houses an incredible collection of archaeological finds from\nacross the Iberian Peninsula. There are items from ancient Greece and Rome,\nalong with artifacts from Egypt and Mesopotamia. Don’t miss the famous La Dama\nde Elche (a bust of a 5th-century Iberian woman) and the Altamira pre-historic\ncave paintings. The Guanche Mummy of Madrid is also here. He was embalmed by\nthe indigenous people of the Canary Islands between the 11th and 13th\ncenturies. Admission is 3 EUR.\n\n##### 5\\. Explore the Naval Museum of Madrid\n\nWhen you think back on the world’s historical naval powers, the 16th-century\nSpanish Armada is sure to come to mind. You can come here to learn about the\nnation’s rich naval history through historic maps from as early as the year\n1500. It also has lots of old drawings, weapons and navigation equipment, and\na really interesting and detailed section on the Spanish Armada. Admission is\nfree but donations of 3 EUR per person are suggested. It’s closed on Mondays.\n\n##### 6\\. Admire some modern art\n\nThe Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía (Reina Sofía National Art\nCenter) offers a fantastic collection of modern art. Works by masters like\nPicasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon can all be found here. The\ncenterpiece of the exhibit is Picasso’s famous Guernica painting, a 1937 oil\npainting that’s considered the most moving anti-war painting in the world.\nWhile I don’t love modern art, even I enjoyed this museum. Admission is 12 EUR\nthough free admission is available from 7pm-9pm on Mondays, Wednesdays,\nThursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays as well as from 12:30-2:30pm on Sundays.\n\n##### 7\\. Shop at the Mercado de San Miguel\n\nThis iconic indoor market is a fun spot to do your grocery shopping. It’s the\noldest covered food market in the city, boasting beautiful 20th-century\narchitecture. It’s a fantastic spot to eat some cheap tapas, pick up\ningredients for supper, or do some people-watching. Open seven days a week,\nthe market is a five-minute walk from Plaza Mayor and attracts the after-work\ndrinks crowd in the evenings.\n\n##### 8\\. See the ancient Temple of Debod\n\nThe Temple of Debod is an Egyptian temple from the 2nd century BCE. It was\ngiven as a gift to Spain by the Egyptian government as a thank you for helping\nthem relocate monuments from the Aswan Dam site (the Aswan Dam is the largest\nembankment dam in the world and was built across the Nile in the 1960s-70s).\nThe temple was rebuilt in Spain between 1970-1972 and can now be found in\nMadrid’s Cuartel de la Montaña Park. Although the inside of the temple is off-\nlimits, you can still walk along the outside. It’s closed on Mondays and\nadmission is free.\n\n##### 9\\. Spend time in the Barrio de La Latina\n\nThis upbeat neighborhood and its maze of narrow lanes and streets lined with\ntapas bars, restaurants, and cantinas is perfect for exploring on foot. If\nyou’re here on Sunday, peruse the offerings at the El Rastro flea market (open\n8am-3pm) and stuff your face at one of the many food stalls. Be sure to step\ninside the 18th century San Francisco el Grand Basilica or the Moorish San\nPedro el Real church, which originally dates to the 14th century.\n\n##### 10\\. See the Plaza de Cibeles\n\nPlaza de Cibeles is a famous plaza in Madrid, located along the central Calle\nde Alcalá and adjacent to Paseo del Prado. Here you can find the Palace of\nCommunications, the city’s mayor’s office, and a Neoclassical 18th-century\nfountain dedicated to the Roman goddess Cybele (the mistress of wild nature).\nThere is an observation deck at the mayor’s office (called the Mirador del\nPalacio de Cibeles) so you can take in the view (closed Mondays). Admission is\n3 EUR.\n\n##### 11\\. Watch a Real Madrid soccer match\n\nMadrid’s soccer team is one of the best, not only in Spain but in the world.\nIf you want to see soccer (or _football_ as they say in Europe) at its best,\ncome watch a game. The stadium is always full, holding over 81,000 people, and\nthe crowds get wild. If you want to experience local life, this is a must.\nTickets start at 35 EUR.\n\n##### 12\\. See the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales\n\nThe Convent of Las Descalzas Reales (which means “Monastery of the Royal\nBarefooted”) was built in the 16th century and was the former palace of\nEmperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal. Unmarried princesses and\n“spinster” noblewomen came here to live as nuns and they brought any wealth\nthey had accumulated with them. These days, just a few nuns look after the\ngrounds and its relics, which include (alleged) pieces of Jesus’s cross and\nthe bones of St. Sebastian, who died around 288 CE. A Spanish Property of\nCultural Interest, inside the building, you can see many works of art. For\nexample, the main staircase is decorated with murals that date to the 16th and\n17th centuries. Admission is 6 EUR.\n\n##### 13\\. Stroll Around the Royal Botanical Garden\n\nSpanning some 20 acres, these botanical gardens are home to more than 5,000\nspecies of plants and trees spread out over four picturesque terraces. There\nare also greenhouses, sculptures, and some immaculately landscaped gardens\nhere too. Founded in 1755, the park has lakes, labyrinths, fountains, and lots\nof flowers that make it a serene and beautiful place to relax. Admission is 4\nEUR.\n\n##### 14\\. Explore the Museo de la Historia de Madrid\n\nMadrid’s Museum of History opened in 1929 and sheds light on the city’s\nevolution from the 16th century (when it became the capital) to World War I.\nIt showcases daily life throughout the ages and offers a nuanced look at\nMadrid via artifacts, maps, paintings, and sculptures, including works by\nfamous artists like Francisco Goya. Admission is free.\n\n##### 15\\. Learn Spanish\n\nIf you have the time, learning the local language is the best way to immerse\nyourself in the culture, meet people, and deepen your understanding of the\ncity. Spanish courses can last for a single week or longer. Many language\nschools offer a variety of affordable housing options, including staying with\na local family. A one-week intensive course starts around 200 EUR and there\nare usually discounts for packages and multi-week courses (the more you book,\nthe more you save).\n\n\n\nFor more information on other cities in Spain, check out these guides:\n\n  * Barcelona Travel Guide\n  * Granada Travel Guide\n\n  * Seville Travel Guide\n\n  * Valencia Travel Guide\n\n### Madrid Travel Costs\n\n  \n**Hostel prices** – Hostel dorms in Madrid vary in price depending on how\nclose the hostel is to the Plaza Mayor. Generally, a bed in a 4-6-bed dorm\nduring peak season (June-August) costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room\nwith 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR.\n\nDuring the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR\nper night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. Free Wi-Fi is standard, and\nmany hostels in the city also include free breakfast.\n\nA basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night\nduring both peak season and off-season.\n\nThere are limited options for camping outside the city and prices are often\nmore than hostels. Most charge around 20-30 EUR per night for a basic tent\nplot without electricity.\n\n**Budget hotel prices** – Budget hotels cost 80-150 EUR per night during peak\nseason. Expect to pay between 65-100 EUR per night in the off-season.",
  "existing_answer": "Nomadic Matt's Travel Site provides a comprehensive Madrid Travel Guide that helps travelers experience the best of Madrid, Spain. The guide is filled with tips on things to see and do, typical costs, money-saving tips, where to stay, how to get around, when to go, how to stay safe, and the best places to book your trip.\n\nThe guide highlights the top 5 things to see and do in Madrid, including strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, and taking a food tour. Other things to see and do include taking a free walking tour, checking out Puerta del Sol, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nThe guide also includes practical information on money-saving tips, such as using public transportation, eating like a local, and avoiding tourist traps. It also provides advice on where to stay, with recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant city."

The guide is filled with tips on things to see and do, typical costs, money-saving tips, where to stay, how to get around, when to go, how to stay safe, and the best places to book your trip.\n\nThe guide highlights the top 5 things to see and do in Madrid, including strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, and taking a food tour. It also provides advice on where to stay, with recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant city.\nWe have the opportunity to refine the existing summary(only if needed) with some more context below.\n------------\n##### 3\\. See flamenco dancers\n\nMadrid has been enjoying flamenco, Spain’s most famous style of dancing, since\nthe early 19th century. Based on the various folkloric music traditions of\nsouthern Spain, flamenco shows take place in many bars and taverns across the\ncity, such as Las Carboneras where you can enjoy a flamenco show with a glass\nof wine and some tapas for 42 EUR. See the ancient Temple of Debod\n\nThe Temple of Debod is an Egyptian temple from the 2nd century BCE. It was\ngiven as a gift to Spain by the Egyptian government as a thank you for helping\nthem relocate monuments from the Aswan Dam site (the Aswan Dam is the largest\nembankment dam in the world and was built across the Nile in the 1960s-70s).\nThe temple was rebuilt in Spain between 1970-1972 and can now be found in\nMadrid’s Cuartel de la Montaña Park. Although the inside of the temple is off-\nlimits, you can still walk along the outside. It’s closed on Mondays and\nadmission is free.\n\n##### 9\\. Spend time in the Barrio de La Latina\n\nThis upbeat neighborhood and its maze of narrow lanes and streets lined with\ntapas bars, restaurants, and cantinas is perfect for exploring on foot. If\nyou’re here on Sunday, peruse the offerings at the El Rastro flea market (open\n8am-3pm) and stuff your face at one of the many food stalls. See the Plaza de Cibeles\n\nPlaza de Cibeles is a famous plaza in Madrid, located along the central Calle\nde Alcalá and adjacent to Paseo del Prado. Here you can find the Palace of\nCommunications, the city’s mayor’s office, and a Neoclassical 18th-century\nfountain dedicated to the Roman goddess Cybele (the mistress of wild nature).\nThere is an observation deck at the mayor’s office (called the Mirador del\nPalacio de Cibeles) so you can take in the view (closed Mondays). Admission is\n3 EUR.\n\n##### 11\\. Watch a Real Madrid soccer match\n\nMadrid’s soccer team is one of the best, not only in Spain but in the world.\nIf you want to see soccer (or _football_ as they say in Europe) at its best,\ncome watch a game. The stadium is always full, holding over 81,000 people, and\nthe crowds get wild. If you want to experience local life, this is a must.\nTickets start at 35 EUR.\n\n##### 12\\. See the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales\n\nThe Convent of Las Descalzas Reales (which means “Monastery of the Royal\nBarefooted”) was built in the 16th century and was the former palace of\nEmperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal. Unmarried princesses and\n“spinster” noblewomen came here to live as nuns and they brought any wealth\nthey had accumulated with them. These days, just a few nuns look after the\ngrounds and its relics, which include (alleged) pieces of Jesus’s cross and\nthe bones of St. Sebastian, who died around 288 CE. A Spanish Property of\nCultural Interest, inside the building, you can see many works of art. For\nexample, the main staircase is decorated with murals that date to the 16th and\n17th centuries. Admission is 6 EUR.\n\n##### 13\\. Stroll Around the Royal Botanical Garden\n\nSpanning some 20 acres, these botanical gardens are home to more than 5,000\nspecies of plants and trees spread out over four picturesque terraces. There\nare also greenhouses, sculptures, and some immaculately landscaped gardens\nhere too. Founded in 1755, the park has lakes, labyrinths, fountains, and lots\nof flowers that make it a serene and beautiful place to relax. Admission is 4\nEUR.\n\n##### 14\\. Explore the Museo de la Historia de Madrid\n\nMadrid’s Museum of History opened in 1929 and sheds light on the city’s\nevolution from the 16th century (when it became the capital) to World War I.\nIt showcases daily life throughout the ages and offers a nuanced look at\nMadrid via artifacts, maps, paintings, and sculptures, including works by\nfamous artists like Francisco Goya. Admission is free.\n\n##### 15\\. Learn Spanish\n\nIf you have the time, learning the local language is the best way to immerse\nyourself in the culture, meet people, and deepen your understanding of the\ncity. Spanish courses can last for a single week or longer. Many language\nschools offer a variety of affordable housing options, including staying with\na local family. A one-week intensive course starts around 200 EUR and there\nare usually discounts for packages and multi-week courses (the more you book,\nthe more you save).\n\n\n\nFor more information on other cities in Spain, check out these guides:\n\n  * Barcelona Travel Guide\n  * Granada Travel Guide\n\n  * Seville Travel Guide\n\n  * Valencia Travel Guide\n\n### Madrid Travel Costs\n\n  \n**Hostel prices** – Hostel dorms in Madrid vary in price depending on how\nclose the hostel is to the Plaza Mayor. Generally, a bed in a 4-6-bed dorm\nduring peak season (June-August) costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room\nwith 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR.\n\nDuring the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR\nper night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. Free Wi-Fi is standard, and\nmany hostels in the city also include free breakfast.\n\nA basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night\nduring both peak season and off-season.\n\nThere are limited options for camping outside the city and prices are often\nmore than hostels. Most charge around 20-30 EUR per night for a basic tent\nplot without electricity.\n\n**Budget hotel prices** – Budget hotels cost 80-150 EUR per night during peak\nseason. Expect to pay between 65-100 EUR per night in the off-season.\n------------\nGiven the new context, refine the original summary to provide a thorough overview of what the city has to offer, including hidden gems, culturalhotspots, must-visit landmarks, weather forecasts, and high level costs."
  ]
}

The guide offers comprehensive information on things to see and do, including the top landmarks such as strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, taking a food tour, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nIn addition to these must-visit landmarks, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history through historic maps, drawings, weapons, and navigation equipment. The guide also recommends visiting the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales, a 16th-century monastery that was the former palace of Emperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal, and now houses many works of art and relics.\n\nFor modern art lovers, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía offers a fantastic collection of modern art, including works by Picasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon.   "text": "Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant city. The guide offers comprehensive information on things to see and do, including the top landmarks such as strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, taking a food tour, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nIn addition to these must-visit landmarks, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history through historic maps, drawings, weapons, and navigation equipment. The guide also recommends visiting the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales, a 16th-century monastery that was the former palace of Emperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal, and now houses many works of art and relics.\n\nFor modern art lovers, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía offers a fantastic collection of modern art, including works by Picasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon. The centerpiece of the exhibit is Picasso’s famous Guernica painting, a 1937 oil painting that’s considered the most moving anti-war painting in the world.\n\nThe guide also provides practical information on money-saving tips, such as using public transportation, eating like a local, and avoiding tourist traps. It also provides advice on where to stay, with recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations.\n\nFor those interested in shopping, the guide recommends visiting the Mercado de San Miguel, an iconic indoor market that is a fun spot to do your grocery shopping, eat some cheap tapas, pick up ingredients for supper, or do some people-watching.\n\nThe guide also includes information on the weather forecasts, which is usually pleasant, with mild winters and hot summers. The best time to visit is during the spring or fall when the weather is mild and the crowds are smaller.\n\nIn terms of costs, a bed in a 4-6-bed dorm during peak season costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR. During the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR per night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. A basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night during both peak season and off-season.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city."

  "text": "* Seville Travel Guide\n\n  * Valencia Travel Guide\n\n### Madrid Travel Costs\n\n  \n**Hostel prices** – Hostel dorms in Madrid vary in price depending on how\nclose the hostel is to the Plaza Mayor. Generally, a bed in a 4-6-bed dorm\nduring peak season (June-August) costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room\nwith 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR.\n\nDuring the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR\nper night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. Free Wi-Fi is standard, and\nmany hostels in the city also include free breakfast.\n\nA basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night\nduring both peak season and off-season.\n\nThere are limited options for camping outside the city and prices are often\nmore than hostels. Most charge around 20-30 EUR per night for a basic tent\nplot without electricity.\n\n**Budget hotel prices** – Budget hotels cost 80-150 EUR per night during peak\nseason. Expect to pay between 65-100 EUR per night in the off-season.\n\nAirbnb is available for those wishing to have more privacy or kitchens to cook\ntheir own food. Private rooms start at 30 EUR per night though they average\ncloser to 70 EUR. Entire homes/apartments average 160 EUR per night though you\ncan find them for as little as 75 EUR if you book early.\n\n**Food** – Spain has a strong food culture, where meals can last hours and\ndinner often isn’t served until after 8pm. Each region in the country has its\nown local dishes and food culture, all of which you can find in Madrid as it’s\nsomething of a culinary hub. Be sure to try local favorites such _patatas\nbravas_ (spicy potatoes), beef stew, _tortilla de patatas_ (Spanish omelet),\nand, of course, churros.\n\nYou can get cheap tapas and meals for around 8-15 EUR. If you want wine\nincluded, expect to spend about 20 EUR. If you go out for paella, drinks, or\nappetizers, then you should plan to spend around 25 EUR for a meal.\n\nLike any city, Madrid has a lot of expensive restaurants, and meals there\nbegin around 35 EUR. On the other end of the spectrum, cheap fast food (think\nMcDonald’s) costs around 8 EUR for a combo meal. Chinese food is around 9-10\nEUR while pizza costs 9-12 EUR for a large.\n\nBeer costs 3-4 EUR while a latte/cappuccino is around 2 EUR. Bottled water is\nless than 1 EUR.\n\nIf you buy your own food, expect to spend about 45-55 EUR for a week’s worth\nof groceries. This gets you basic staples like pasta, rice, seasonal produce,\nand some meat.\n\n### Backpacking Madrid Suggested Budgets\n\nIf you’re backpacking Madrid, expect to spend around 55 EUR per day. This\nbudget covers staying in a hostel dorm, cooking most of your meals, limiting\nyour drinking, taking public transportation to get around, and doing mostly\nfree activities like free walking tours and relaxing in the parks. Add 10-20\nEUR per day to your budget if you plan on drinking or partying a lot.\n\nOn a mid-range budget of 140 EUR per day, you can stay in a private Airbnb or\nprivate hostel room, eat out at cheap restaurants for most meals, enjoy a few\ndrinks, take the occasional taxi to get around, and do more paid activities\nlike cooking classes and museum visits.\n\nOn a “luxury” budget of 275 EUR or more per day, you can stay in a hotel, eat\nout anywhere you want, drink as much as you’d like, take more taxis, and do as\nmany guided tours as you want. This is just the ground floor for luxury\nthough. The sky is the limit!\n\nYou can use the chart below to get an idea of how much you need to budget\ndaily. Keep in mind these are daily averages – some days you spend more, some\ndays you spend less (you might spend less every day). We just want to give you\na general idea of how to make your budget. Prices are in EUR.\n\nAccommodation\n\nFood\n\nTransportation\n\nAttractions\n\nAverage Daily Cost\n\nBackpacker\n\n20\n\n15\n\n10\n\n10\n\n55\n\nMid-Range\n\n75\n\n40\n\n15\n\n20\n\n140\n\nLuxury\n\n120\n\n90\n\n25\n\n40\n\n275\n\n### Madrid Travel Guide: Money-Saving Tips\n\nMadrid can be an expensive city, especially if you indulge in the city’s famed\nfood and drink. Those costs can add up quickly. Fortunately, you can trim your\ncosts if you follow a few simple tips and tricks. Here are some general ways\nto save money in Madrid:\n\n  * **Eat a large lunch** – Lunch is much cheaper than dinner in Madrid and you can find “menu del día” which costs around 10-15 EUR for a large meal with a glass of wine or beer.\n  * **Get the Madrid tourist card** – The often-overlooked Madrid Card offers free public transportation, free access to Prado and other museums, as well as all sorts of discounts at nightclubs, entertainment facilities, shops, and restaurants. You can purchase a 24-hour card for 47 EUR, a 48-hour card for 60 EUR, a 72-hour card for 67 EUR, or a 120-hour card for 77 EUR.\n  * **Embrace free museum days** – Lots of museums in Madrid are free on certain days or at certain times throughout the day. Be sure to check before you go because it’s far better to see sights like the Prado for free! You can ask at the tourism office as they hold a list there.\n  * **Stay with a local** – Couchsurfing is a great way to save money on accommodation while also getting some insight from the locals. While hostels aren’t too expensive in the city, this is still the best way to save money and connect with an insider who can share their expert tips and advice.\n  * **Take a free walking tour** – This is one of my favorite ways to get to know a new destination — and you can’t beat the price! New Europe Walking Tours and Cat’s Hostel Walking Tours are the two most popular free tours in the city.\n  * **Grocery shop at the markets** – Fresh food can be bought for cheap at some of the daily markets in the city. Check out the Mercado de la Paz or Mercado de Maravillas for fresh produce and meat. You’ll save a ton compared to the supermarket. \n  * **Bring a water bottle** – The tap water here is safe to drink so bring a reusable water bottle to save money and reduce your plastic use. LifeStraw is my go-to brand as their bottles have built-in filters to ensure your water is always clean and safe.\n\n### Where to Stay in Madrid\n\nMadrid has a ton of hostel choices. Here are the best hostels in Madrid:\n\n  * The Hat Hostel\n  * OK Hostel\n  * Barbieri Sol Hostel\n  * Sungate One\n  * Cats Hostel\n\n### How to Get Around Madrid\n\n  \n**Public transportation** – The best way to get around Madrid is to use the\nsubway or take tbe us. The base fare is 1.50 EUR for the first five stations\n(one-way) then an additional 0.10 EUR for each additional station up to a 2\nEUR maximum in central Madrid.\n\nPublic buses run all over Madrid from 6:30am-11:30pm (with some night routes\nalso) and they cost the same as the metro. You can also get 10-journey cards\nfrom 11.20 EUR depending on your zones.\n\nTourist passes are available for unlimited usage on all public transportation,\nranging from 1-7 days. They cost 8.40-70.80 EUR depending on the zones you\nneed.\n\n**Bicycle** – Madrid has an electric bike-sharing program called BiciMAD.\nRentals start at 2 EUR per hour and then it’s 4 EUR per extra hour.\n\n**Taxis** – Taxis start at 3.25 EUR and then 1.10 EUR per additional\nkilometer. Skip them if you can as prices add up fast!\n\n**Ridesharing** – Uber is available in Madrid.\n\n**Car rental** – Car rentals can be found for as little as 25 EUR per day for\na multi-day rental, however, you don’t need a car to get around the city.\nUnless you’re going to explore the surrounding region, skip the car rental.\n\n### When to Go to Madrid\n\nMadrid is a year-round destination like the rest of Spain, but during peak\nseason (June-August) crowds are heavy, prices are highest, and the heat is\noppressive. Daily temperatures soar well above 30°C (86°F) in the summer so\nplan for hot weather. While the city is lively, you’ll need to book everything\nin advance as places sell out.",

The guide offers comprehensive information on things to see and do, including the top landmarks such as strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, taking a food tour, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nIn addition to these must-visit landmarks, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history through historic maps, drawings, weapons, and navigation equipment. The centerpiece of the exhibit is Picasso’s famous Guernica painting, a 1937 oil painting that’s considered the most moving anti-war painting in the world.\n\nThe guide also provides practical information on money-saving tips, such as using public transportation, eating like a local, and avoiding tourist traps. It also provides advice on where to stay, with recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations.\n\nFor those interested in shopping, the guide recommends visiting the Mercado de San Miguel, an iconic indoor market that is a fun spot to do your grocery shopping, eat some cheap tapas, pick up ingredients for supper, or do some people-watching.\n\nThe guide also includes information on the weather forecasts, which is usually pleasant, with mild winters and hot summers. The best time to visit is during the spring or fall when the weather is mild and the crowds are smaller.\n\nIn terms of costs, a bed in a 4-6-bed dorm during peak season costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR. During the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR per night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. A basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night during both peak season and off-season.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city."

While hostels aren’t too expensive in the city, this is still the best way to save money and connect with an insider who can share their expert tips and advice.\n  * **Take a free walking tour** – This is one of my favorite ways to get to know a new destination — and you can’t beat the price! New Europe Walking Tours and Cat’s Hostel Walking Tours are the two most popular free tours in the city.\n  * **Grocery shop at the markets** – Fresh food can be bought for cheap at some of the daily markets in the city. Check out the Mercado de la Paz or Mercado de Maravillas for fresh produce and meat. You’ll save a ton compared to the supermarket. \n  * **Bring a water bottle** – The tap water here is safe to drink so bring a reusable water bottle to save money and reduce your plastic use. LifeStraw is my go-to brand as their bottles have built-in filters to ensure your water is always clean and safe.\n\n### Where to Stay in Madrid\n\nMadrid has a ton of hostel choices. Here are the best hostels in Madrid:\n\n  * The Hat Hostel\n  * OK Hostel\n  * Barbieri Sol Hostel\n  * Sungate One\n  * Cats Hostel\n\n### How to Get Around Madrid\n\n  \n**Public transportation** – The best way to get around Madrid is to use the\nsubway or take tbe us. The base fare is 1.50 EUR for the first five stations\n(one-way) then an additional 0.10 EUR for each additional station up to a 2\nEUR maximum in central Madrid.\n\nPublic buses run all over Madrid from 6:30am-11:30pm (with some night routes\nalso) and they cost the same as the metro. You can also get 10-journey cards\nfrom 11.20 EUR depending on your zones.\n\nTourist passes are available for unlimited usage on all public transportation,\nranging from 1-7 days. They cost 8.40-70.80 EUR depending on the zones you\nneed.\n\n**Bicycle** – Madrid has an electric bike-sharing program called BiciMAD.\nRentals start at 2 EUR per hour and then it’s 4 EUR per extra hour.\n\n**Taxis** – Taxis start at 3.25 EUR and then 1.10 EUR per additional\nkilometer. Skip them if you can as prices add up fast!\n\n**Ridesharing** – Uber is available in Madrid.\n\n**Car rental** – Car rentals can be found for as little as 25 EUR per day for\na multi-day rental, however, you don’t need a car to get around the city.\nUnless you’re going to explore the surrounding region, skip the car rental.\n\n### When to Go to Madrid\n\nMadrid is a year-round destination like the rest of Spain, but during peak\nseason (June-August) crowds are heavy, prices are highest, and the heat is\noppressive. Daily temperatures soar well above 30°C (86°F) in the summer so\nplan for hot weather. While the city is lively, you’ll need to book everything\nin advance as places sell out.\n------------\nGiven the new context, refine the original summary to provide a thorough overview of what the city has to offer, including hidden gems, culturalhotspots, must-visit landmarks, weather forecasts, and high level costs."
  ]
}

        "text": "Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city. The guide offers comprehensive information on things to see and do, including top landmarks such as strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, taking a food tour, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nIn addition to these must-visit landmarks, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history through historic maps, drawings, weapons, and navigation equipment. The guide also recommends visiting the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales, a 16th-century monastery that was the former palace of Emperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal, and now houses many works of art and relics. For modern art lovers, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía offers a fantastic collection of modern art, including works by Picasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon. The centerpiece of the exhibit is Picasso’s famous Guernica painting, a 1937 oil painting that’s considered the most moving anti-war painting in the world.\n\nThe guide also provides practical information on money-saving tips, such as using public transportation, eating like a local, and avoiding tourist traps. It also provides advice on where to stay, with recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations. For those interested in shopping, the guide recommends visiting the Mercado de San Miguel, an iconic indoor market that is a fun spot to do your grocery shopping, eat some cheap tapas, pick up ingredients for supper, or do some people-watching.\n\nThe guide includes information on the weather forecasts, which is usually pleasant, with mild winters and hot summers. The best time to visit is during the spring or fall when the weather is mild and the crowds are smaller.\n\nIn terms of costs, a bed in a 4-6-bed dorm during peak season costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR. During the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR per night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. A basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night during both peak season and off-season. There are limited options for camping outside the city and prices are often more than hostels. Most charge around 20-30 EUR per night for a basic tent plot without electricity.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city.",

The guide offers comprehensive information on things to see and do, including top landmarks such as strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, taking a food tour, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nIn addition to these must-visit landmarks, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history through historic maps, drawings, weapons, and navigation equipment. The guide also recommends visiting the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales, a 16th-century monastery that was the former palace of Emperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal, and now houses many works of art and relics. For modern art lovers, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía offers a fantastic collection of modern art, including works by Picasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon. The centerpiece of the exhibit is Picasso’s famous Guernica painting, a 1937 oil painting that’s considered the most moving anti-war painting in the world.\n\nThe guide also provides practical information on money-saving tips, such as using public transportation, eating like a local, and avoiding tourist traps. It also provides advice on where to stay, with recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations. For those interested in shopping, the guide recommends visiting the Mercado de San Miguel, an iconic indoor market that is a fun spot to do your grocery shopping, eat some cheap tapas, pick up ingredients for supper, or do some people-watching.\n\nThe guide includes information on the weather forecasts, which is usually pleasant, with mild winters and hot summers. The best time to visit is during the spring or fall when the weather is mild and the crowds are smaller.\n\nIn terms of costs, a bed in a 4-6-bed dorm during peak season costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR. During the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR per night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. A basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night during both peak season and off-season. There are limited options for camping outside the city and prices are often more than hostels. Most charge around 20-30 EUR per night for a basic tent plot without electricity.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city."

Skip them if you can as prices add up fast!\n\n**Ridesharing** – Uber is available in Madrid.\n\n**Car rental** – Car rentals can be found for as little as 25 EUR per day for\na multi-day rental, however, you don’t need a car to get around the city.\nUnless you’re going to explore the surrounding region, skip the car rental.\n\n### When to Go to Madrid\n\nMadrid is a year-round destination like the rest of Spain, but during peak\nseason (June-August) crowds are heavy, prices are highest, and the heat is\noppressive. Daily temperatures soar well above 30°C (86°F) in the summer so\nplan for hot weather. While the city is lively, you’ll need to book everything\nin advance as places sell out.\n\nPersonally, I think the shoulder season is the best time to visit Madrid\n(April-May and September-October). Tourist sites are much less congested and\nprices for accommodation are lower. Temperatures are pleasant, with average\ntemperatures hovering around 64°F (18°C). Just bring a raincoat in case there\nare brief showers.\n\nVisiting in the winter is also doable, though the days can be chilly. While\nthe weather isn’t great, you’ll get much of the sights to yourself and prices\nwill be lower. Expect daily highs around 10°C (50°F).\n\n### How to Stay Safe in Madrid\n\nMadrid is a safe city. Violent crime is very rare , though pickpocketing and\npetty theft are common, especially in the major tourist areas and on the\nmetro. You need to be really careful with your stuff and always watch your\npockets when you’re out and about — especially while on public transportation.\nThe pickpockets here (and in Spain in general) a very talented!\n\nIf you go out at night, only bring the money you need. Leave the rest in your\naccommodation just in case.\n\nSolo female travelers should feel safe here. However, the standard precautions\napply (don’t leave your drink unattended at the bar, don’t walk around\nintoxicated at night, etc.). It’s a cheaper and more interesting way to travel than by bus or train! \n  * **Take Walks** – This walking tour company provides inside access to attractions and places you can’t get elsewhere. Their guides rock and they have some of the best and most insightful tours in all of Spain.\n\n### Madrid Travel Guide: Related Articles\n\nWant more info? Check out all the articles I’ve written on Spain travel and\ncontinue planning your trip:\n\n  * #### The Best Walking Tours in Seville\n\n  * #### The Perfect 3 Day Granada Itinerary\n\n  * #### The 7 Best Hostels in Seville\n\n  * #### The 7 Best Hostels in Madrid\n\n  * #### The Best, Most Delicious Food Tour in Madrid\n\n  * #### The Best Walking Tours in Madrid\n\nClick here for more articles--->\n\n### Get my best stuff sent straight to you!\n\nSend Me Tips\n\n#### About Us\n\n  * About Matt\n  * Meet the Team\n  * Write for Us\n  * Contact Us\n  * Copyright\n  * Privacy Policy\n\n#### Travel Tips\n\n  * Start Here\n  * Travel Blog\n  * Destination Guides\n  * Travel Credit Cards\n\n#### Book Your Trip\n\n  * Accommodation\n  * Cheap Flights\n  * Travel Insurance\n  * Favorite Hostels\n  * Favorite Neighborhoods\n  * Favorite Companies\n\n#### Books And Courses\n\n  * Ten Years a Nomad\n  * Destination Guidebooks\n  * Blogging Mentorship\n  * Writing Mentorship\n\n#### Follow Me on the Web\n\n#### Search\n\nCopyright © 2024 · Nomadic Matt’s Travel Site\n\n### Pin It on Pinterest\n\n  * See and Do\n  * Costs\n  * Where To Stay\n  * Transportation\n  * When To Go\n  * Safety\n  * Booking Resources\n  * Related Blogs\n\nNomadic Matt  \nData and Cookie Consent\n\nIn order to provide a more personal user experience, we and our 219 partners\nuse technology such as cookies to store and/or access device information.\n\nBy clicking “Accept” you consent to these technologies which will allow us and\n\nour partners\n------------\nGiven the new context, refine the original summary to provide a thorough overview of what the city has to offer, including hidden gems, culturalhotspots, must-visit landmarks, weather forecasts, and high level costs."

      {
        "text": "Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city. The guide offers comprehensive information on things to see and do, including top landmarks such as strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, taking a food tour, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nIn addition to these must-visit landmarks, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history through historic maps, drawings, weapons, and navigation equipment. The guide also recommends visiting the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales, a 16th-century monastery that was the former palace of Emperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal, and now houses many works of art and relics. For modern art lovers, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía offers a fantastic collection of modern art, including works by Picasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon. The centerpiece of the exhibit is Picasso’s famous Guernica painting, a 1937 oil painting that’s considered the most moving anti-war painting in the world.\n\nThe guide also provides practical information on money-saving tips, such as using public transportation, eating like a local, and avoiding tourist traps. It includes details on Madrid's electric bike-sharing program, BiciMAD, as well as information on taxis, ridesharing with Uber, and car rentals. However, it notes that a car is not necessary to get around the city and is only recommended for exploring the surrounding region.\n\nThe guide includes information on the weather forecasts, which is usually pleasant, with mild winters and hot summers. The best time to visit is during the spring or fall when the weather is mild and the crowds are smaller.\n\nFor accommodation, the guide provides recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations, and includes information on costs. A bed in a 4-6-bed dorm during peak season costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR. During the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR per night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. A basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night during both peak season and off-season. There are limited options for camping outside the city and prices are often more than hostels.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city.",

  "text": "Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city. The guide offers comprehensive information on things to see and do, including top landmarks such as strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, taking a food tour, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nIn addition to these must-visit landmarks, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history through historic maps, drawings, weapons, and navigation equipment. The guide also recommends visiting the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales, a 16th-century monastery that was the former palace of Emperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal, and now houses many works of art and relics. For modern art lovers, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía offers a fantastic collection of modern art, including works by Picasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon. The centerpiece of the exhibit is Picasso’s famous Guernica painting, a 1937 oil painting that’s considered the most moving anti-war painting in the world.\n\nThe guide also provides practical information on money-saving tips, such as using public transportation, eating like a local, and avoiding tourist traps. It includes details on Madrid's electric bike-sharing program, BiciMAD, as well as information on taxis, ridesharing with Uber, and car rentals. However, it notes that a car is not necessary to get around the city and is only recommended for exploring the surrounding region.\n\nThe guide includes information on the weather forecasts, which is usually pleasant, with mild winters and hot summers. The best time to visit is during the spring or fall when the weather is mild and the crowds are smaller.\n\nFor accommodation, the guide provides recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations, and includes information on costs. A bed in a 4-6-bed dorm during peak season costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR. During the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR per night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. A basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night during both peak season and off-season. There are limited options for camping outside the city and prices are often more than hostels.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city."

  "existing_answer": "Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city. The guide offers comprehensive information on things to see and do, including top landmarks such as strolling Plaza Mayor, visiting the Prado Museum, unwinding in El Retiro Park, visiting the Palacio Real, taking a food tour, seeing flamenco dancers, and visiting the National Archaeological Museum.\n\nIn addition to these must-visit landmarks, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history through historic maps, drawings, weapons, and navigation equipment. The guide also recommends visiting the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales, a 16th-century monastery that was the former palace of Emperor Charles V and Empress Isabel of Portugal, and now houses many works of art and relics. For modern art lovers, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía offers a fantastic collection of modern art, including works by Picasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon. The centerpiece of the exhibit is Picasso’s famous Guernica painting, a 1937 oil painting that’s considered the most moving anti-war painting in the world.\n\nThe guide also provides practical information on money-saving tips, such as using public transportation, eating like a local, and avoiding tourist traps. It includes details on Madrid's electric bike-sharing program, BiciMAD, as well as information on taxis, ridesharing with Uber, and car rentals. However, it notes that a car is not necessary to get around the city and is only recommended for exploring the surrounding region.\n\nThe guide includes information on the weather forecasts, which is usually pleasant, with mild winters and hot summers. The best time to visit is during the spring or fall when the weather is mild and the crowds are smaller.\n\nFor accommodation, the guide provides recommendations for budget, mid-range, and luxury accommodations, and includes information on costs. A bed in a 4-6-bed dorm during peak season costs about 24 EUR, while a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs 19 EUR. During the off-season, a bed in a room with 8 beds or more costs from 14 EUR per night while smaller rooms cost about 18 EUR. A basic private room for two with a private bathroom costs 55-90 EUR per night during both peak season and off-season. There are limited options for camping outside the city and prices are often more than hostels.\n\nOverall, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing valuable insights and tips to help travelers make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city."
}

Honestly, I would’ve likely\nmissed out on the **best things to do in Madrid** without it. So, to help you\nplan your trip, I’m here to pass on my Madrid itinerary to you.\n\n**Disclosure:** Travel Lemming is an independent reader-supported blog. You\ncan support us by purchasing via the affiliate links on this page, which may\nearn us commissions. See our Advertising Policy for further explanation. Thank\nyou!\n\n## 6-Day Madrid Itinerary\n\n🖨️  **Get a printable version of this itinerary**\n\n### Day 1 – Plaza Mayor, Gran Via, And The Royal Palace\n\n_Buildings along Gran Via shopping street_\n\n#### Morning 🌅\n\nOn your first morning in Madrid, sit down at **La Rollerie** on Calle Mayor\nand order the restaurant’s Iberian Brunch.\n\nNext, walk five minutes away to **Plaza Mayor** , one of the most iconic\nattractions in Madrid. After a little people-watching, check out **Puerta del\nSol** five minutes away and its famous statue of a bear and a tree.\n\n**👉 Pro Tip:** Puerta del Sol is right in the city center, so it’s a great\nplace to stay in Madrid. **Hotel Moderno Puerta del Sol **is one of the best\nhotels in this area.  \n\n#### Afternoon ☀️\n\nIn the afternoon, take a stroll through Madrid 15 minutes away to **Gran Via**\n, Madrid’s most famous street. Wander and shop around the busy avenue before\nstopping for a tapas lunch at **Desengaño 13.  **\n\nThen, swing by **Santa Eulalia** about 10 minutes away from the restaurant to\npick up some sweet baked goods to bring with you for later.  \n\nWhen you have your baking, head over to the **Royal Palace of Madrid** next to\nthe gardens, the official residence of the Spanish royal family. While you can\ntechnically explore by yourself, I recommend you take this **Madrid royal\npalace expert guided tour** to finish the afternoon **.**\n\n#### Evening 🌇\n\nAt dusk, take a walk around **Campo Del Moro Gardens** right next to the Royal\nPalace, or hang out on a bench in **Sabatini Gardens** to munch on your\npastries.\n\nFor dinner, reserve a table at **Restaurante Amicis,** and make sure you try\nthe duck tacos (I can confirm they’re delicious). After the meal, sip down a\ncocktail or two at **Bad Company 1920**.\n\n### Day 2 – Retiro Park, Art Museums, and Nightlife\n\n_Monuments in El Retiro Park_\n\n#### Morning 🌅\n\nGive yourself a little boost on your second morning in Madrid with coffee and\na croissant from **Misión Café** in the Malasaña neighborhood. After\nbreakfast, walk just five minutes away to **Plaza de España** to see its\nstatues and gardens.\n\nNext, take a taxi or the bus over to **Museo del Prado,** one of the **best\nmuseums in Spain**. Here you’ll wander through one of the best collections of\nEuropean art by masters like El Greco, Velazquez, and Goya. Then, hit the\n**Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum,** again, just a five-minute walk away.\n\n#### Afternoon ☀️\n\nFor lunch, head to **East 47 Restaurant- Bar,** and don’t leave without\nordering the tuna tataki. When you’ve finished your meal, walk 10 minutes to\nPlaza de la Independencia where you’ll see the famous **Puerta de Alcalá**\nlandmark of Madrid.\n\nThen, head inside **El Retiro Park** right next to the plaza to explore the\ngreenery, rose gardens, and the Palacio de Cristal. Once you’ve taken a stroll\naround the grounds, rent a rowboat at the Great Pond of El Retiro and paddle\naway.\n\n#### Evening 🌇\n\nIn the evening, catch an opera performance at the famed **Teatro Real** that’s\nbeen in operation since 1850. After the show, relax at **El miniBAR** for a\nfew hours and order a spread of 5 to 10 tapas dishes with drinks.\n\nAt around midnight, go to **Planet Club** to get some more drinks and go\ndancing into the wee hours of the morning. Then, keep the party going at\n**Opium Madrid**.\n\nFinish off the evening at the 129-year-old **Chocolateria San Gines** for\nchurros dipped in thick, rich chocolate. It’s open 24 hours a day over the\nweekend, so it’ll be available no matter what time you’re done partying.\n\n### Day 3 – Toledo Day Trip\n\n_Views over the Alcazar royal palace in Toledo_\n\n#### Morning 🌅\n\nWith only a few days of your itinerary left, it’s time to take a **day trip\nfrom Madrid** to an incredible city called **Toledo**.\n\nArrive at **Puerta de Atocha Train Station** early in the morning and check\nout the Madrid station’s botanical garden. Then, catch the train from Madrid\nto Toledo for around $16 and take the 35-minute ride.\n\nUpon arrival in the ancient city of Toledo, either take a 25-minute walk or a\n10-minute cab ride to the Old Town. Walk over to **Teteria Dar Al Chai** , a\ntraditional teahouse, for hot Indian tea and crepes.\n\nAfter breakfast, check out **Santa Iglesia Catedral Primada de Toledo** and\nits impressive art collection that includes works by Caravaggio, Raphael, and\nmore. Then, pay a visit to the **Museum of Manchego Cheese** just a minute\naway for a cheese tasting and tour.\n\n#### Afternoon ☀️\n\n_The Alcazar de Toledo on a sunny day (photo: Sun_Shine / Shutterstock)_\n\nFive minutes away from the cheese museum, purchase tickets to **Alcázar de\nToledo** and explore the 16th-century royal palace. Then take a 15-minute walk\nthrough the Old Town to reach **Museo del Greco** and get a feel for the\nfamous painter El Greco.\n\nNext, munch on a surprisingly affordable lunch at the **Michelin star\nRestaurante La Orza**. Following the delicious meal, take photos at **San\nMartin’s Bridge** over the Tagus River and stroll across.\n\nThen, get a taxi up to **Mirador del Valle** to relax, see panoramic views of\nToledo, and take photos of the surrounding area.\n\n#### Evening 🌇",
  "existing_answer": "Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is an essential resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, providing comprehensive information on the city's rich history, culture, and landmarks. The guide offers practical tips for making the most of your visit, including money-saving advice on transportation, accommodation, and dining.\n\nSome of the must-visit landmarks in Madrid include the Plaza Mayor, Prado Museum, El Retiro Park, Palacio Real, and the National Archaeological Museum. However, the guide also highlights some hidden gems, such as the Naval Museum of Madrid, which showcases the nation’s rich naval history, and the Monasterio de las Descalzas Reales, a 16th-century monastery that houses many works of art and relics. For modern art lovers, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía offers a fantastic collection of modern art, including works by Picasso, Miró, Kandinsky, Dalí, and Bacon.\n\nThe guide provides detailed information on accommodation options, from budget hostels to luxury hotels, with prices ranging from 14 EUR per night for a bed in a room with 8 beds or more during the off-season to 90 EUR per night for a basic private room for two with a private bathroom during both peak and off-peak seasons.\n\nMadrid's weather is usually pleasant, with mild winters and hot summers. The best time to visit is during the spring or fall when the weather is mild and the crowds are smaller. The guide includes information on transportation options, including public transportation, electric bike-sharing program BiciMAD, taxis, ridesharing with Uber, and car rentals.\n\nNomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is part of a larger website that offers travel tips, destination guides, travel credit cards, accommodation recommendations, and books and courses for travelers. The website also includes a blog, booking resources, and information on following Nomadic Matt on social media.\n\nIn summary, Nomadic Matt's Madrid Travel Guide is a valuable resource for anyone planning a trip to Madrid, offering comprehensive information on the city's must-visit landmarks, hidden gems, cultural hotspots, weather forecasts, and high-level costs. The guide's practical tips and money-saving advice make it an essential tool for travelers looking to make the most of their time in this vibrant and culturally-rich city."
}
